Open-R1 Training API¶

The common.open_r1 package now hosts the shared reinforcement learning utilities used by the GRPO and GRAIL training loops. The concrete training entry points live under grpo.grpo and grail.grail, while the remaining helpers cover configuration, data loading, rollout orchestration, and evaluation. Use the modules below to explore the available configuration surfaces and helper tooling.

Reward Output Format¶

The GRPO prompts built by common.open_r1 now expect two committed answers from the policy. Every completion must follow this layout:

<think>…</think><answer>2</answer><opinion>decrease</opinion>

  • <answer>…</answer> continues to identify the next-video choice by its 1-based index in the slate.

  • <opinion>…</opinion> captures the viewer’s predicted opinion direction and must be one of increase, decrease, or no_change.

The training dataset exposes this supervision via the opinion_direction column, and common.open_r1.rewards.pure_accuracy_reward() now awards partial credit when a completion correctly predicts one task but not the other. See the reward module API below for additional details.

Penalise overlong completions without rewarding shorter ones.

Parameters:

  • max_completion_len (int) – Maximum allowed completion length.

  • soft_punish_cache (int) – Buffer length before the hard penalty applies.

Reward function that softly penalises long completions.

Return type:

Callable[[list[list[int]]], list[float]]

common.open_r1.rewards.len_reward(completions, solution, **kwargs)[source]¶

Compute length-based rewards to discourage overthinking and promote token efficiency.

Taken from the Kimi 1.5 tech report: https://huggingface.co/papers/2501.12599

Parameters:

  • completions (list[Dict[str, str]]) – List of model completions.

  • solution (list[str]) – List of ground truth solutions.

  • kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments (unused).

Returns:

List of rewards where: - For correct answers: reward = 0.5 - (len - min_len)/(max_len - min_len) - For incorrect answers: reward = min(0, 0.5 - (len - min_len)/(max_len - min_len))

Return type:

list[float]

common.open_r1.rewards.pure_accuracy_reward(completions, _answer=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Score completions on next-video accuracy and opinion-direction agreement.

Steps:

  1. Parse the numeric answer from <answer>…</answer> (or bare numbers when the PUREACC_ALLOW_BARE_NUMBER environment flag is enabled) and compare it against gold_index (1-based).

  2. Parse <opinion>…</opinion> (or aliases) and compare it to the canonicalised opinion_direction label (increase/decrease/no_change).

  3. Return the average reward across the available sub-tasks so the model earns partial credit when only one prediction is correct.

Parameters:

  • completions (list[Any]) – Model completions whose answers should be evaluated.

  • _answer (list[str] | None) – Optional compatibility argument (falls back to answer in kwargs).

  • kwargs (dict) – Additional metadata such as gold_index, n_options, and opinion_direction.

Returns:

Per-sample rewards in the inclusive range [0.0, 1.0].

Return type:

list[float]

common.open_r1.rewards.tag_count_reward(completions, **kwargs)[source]¶

Reward function that checks if we produce the desired number of think and answer tags associated with the formatting guard.

Adapted from: https://gist.github.com/willccbb/4676755236bb08cab5f4e54a0475d6fb#file-grpo_demo-py-L90

Parameters:

  • completions (list[list[dict[str, str]]]) – Chat-style completions produced by the policy.

  • kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments (unused).

Returns:

Partial rewards for each completion based on tag presence.

Trainer callbacks that integrate Open-R1 runs with auxiliary services.

The callbacks defined here extend Hugging Face Trainer runs with behaviour used by the Open-R1 experiments, focusing on pushing checkpoints to the Hub. The functions are written to be picked up by Sphinx autodoc so they show up in the generated API reference.

common.open_r1.utils.evaluation.register_lighteval_task(configs, eval_suite, task_name, task_list, num_fewshot=0)[source]¶

Register a LightEval task configuration.

Notes

  • Core tasks can be added from this table: https://github.com/huggingface/lighteval/blob/main/src/lighteval/tasks/tasks_table.jsonl

  • Custom tasks requiring bespoke metrics or scripts should live in scripts/evaluation/extended_lighteval_tasks.

Parameters:

  • configs (dict[str, str]) – Dictionary used to store the task configuration.

  • eval_suite (str) – Evaluation suite to pull tasks from.

  • task_name (str) – Display name for the task.

  • task_list (str) – Comma-separated task list using the LightEval format: extended|{task_name}|{num_fewshot}|0 or lighteval|{task_name}|{num_fewshot}|0.

  • num_fewshot (int) – Number of few-shot examples.

common.open_r1.utils.hub.get_param_count_from_repo_id(repo_id)[source]¶

Return parameter count from safetensors metadata or repo naming pattern.

The repo ID can include human-readable counts such as 42m, 1.5b, 0.5m, or products like 8x7b. If metadata is unavailable, those tokens are parsed to estimate the parameter count.

Parameters:

repo_id (str) – Hugging Face repository identifier.

Returns:

Approximate parameter count, or -1 when it cannot be determined.

Return type:

int
